committees: Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union
description: Read, and committed to the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to which the bill H.R. No. 73 is committed. Mr. Everett submitted the following, which, when the bill H.R. No. 73, ''for the apportionment of Representatives among the several States according to the sixth census,'' shall be taken up for consideration, he will move as an Amendment. Strike out (the ratio of) sixty-eight thousand, and insert fifty thousand three hundred and ninety-one, (constituting a House of three hundred and five members, under which the present representation of no State will be decreased;) and (with a view to test the sense of the committee between a low and a high ratio) that he will move to amend the amendment by striking out fifty thousand three hundred and ninety-one, and inserting seventy thousand six hundred and eighty, (constituting a House of two hundred and seventeen members.)

Amendment Proposed by Mr. Everett. That, from and after the third day of March, eighteen hundred and forty-three, the House of Representatives shall be composed of members elected agreeably to the ratio that shall, in each State, approximate nearest to the ratio of one Representative for every seventy thousand six hundred and eighty persons in each State, computed according to the rule prescribed by the Constitution of the United States.

Mr. Smith, of Indiana, from the Committee on Public Lands, to whom was referred the bill (H.R. 334) in relation to the exemplifications of the records of land patents, and other evidences of title, and amendatory of the act entitled ''An act to re-organize the General Land Office,'' reported the same with the following Amendments. Strike out preamble. Strike out third section, and insert in lieu thereof, from the words ''And be it further enacted,'' That so much of the act entitled ''An act to reorganize the General Land Office, as authorizes the President of the United States, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, to appoint a secretary to sign patents for lands sold or granted under the authority of the United States, be, and the same is hereby, repealed, and the said office of secretary to sign patents be, and the same is hereby, abolished, and the duties required to be performed by him shall be hereafter performed by the Recorder of the General Land Office, without any additional compensation therefor.

Mr. Bates, from the Committee on Pensions, to whom was referred the bill (H.R. 665), ''granting a pension to certain revolutionary soldiers,'' reported the same with the following Amendments. Strike out all after the enacting clause, and insert the following: That the widow of any person who served in the war of the Revolution in the manner set forth in the act approved the seventh day of June, eighteen hundred and thirty-two, entitled ''An act supplementary to the act for the relief of certain surviving officers and soldiers of the Revolution,'' and whose widow, in virtue of an act approved the seventh day of July, eighteen hundred and thirty-eight, entitled ''An act granting half pay and pensions to certain widows,'' and an act approved the twenty-third day of August, eighteen hundred and forty-two, amendatory thereof, and a resolution approved the sixteenth day of August, eighteen hundred and forty-two, entitled ''A resolution declarative of the pension act of July the seventh, eighteen hundred and thirty-eight,'' received, or is entitled to an annuity or pension for the term of five years from the fourth of March, eighteen hundred and thirty-six, shall be entitled to receive the same annuity or pension which she received, or is entitled to receive, under said acts or said resolution, or either of them, for and during the further term of five years from the fourth day of March, eighteen hundred and forty-three, or during such portion of said term as said widow shall survive, subject in all respects, however, to the rules, limitations, and conditions, in and by said acts and resolution made and provided.

Whereas there were in the employment of the United States, and connected with the collection of the public revenue by impost duties at the port of New York, on the first day of January, one thousand eight hundred and twenty-eight, one hundred and sixty-four persons, and on the first day of January, one thousand eight hundred and forty-two, there were so employed at said port five hundred and two persons; and whereas the annual pay and salaries of said one hundred and sixty-four persons thus employed on the said first day of January, one thousand eight hundred and twenty-eight, amounted to the sum of one hundred and twelve thousand nine hundred and seventy dollars, and the annual pay and salaries of said five hundred and two persons thus employed on the first day of January, one thousand eight hundred and forty-two, amounted to the sum of four hundred and eighty-nine thousand five hundred and twenty-three dollars and fifty-three cents, and whereas the gross amount of revenue collected at said port of New York in the year one thousand eight hundred and twenty-six was eleven million five hundred and eighty-two thousand five hundred and forty-seven dollars and twenty-two cents, and in the year one thousand eight hundred and twenty-seven was thirteen million two hundred and seventy-two thousand five hundred and twenty-six dollars and fifty-four cents, and in the year one thousand eight hundred and forty the gross revenue collected at said port was seven million six hundred and twenty-three thousand and ninety-nine dollars and sixty-six cents, and in the year one thousand eight hundred and forty-one was ten million nine hundred and thirty-two thousand one hundred, and seventeen dollars and ninety-eight cents: Wherefore,
